questions.title: EM/GMM [2 pts]

choices.answer: We know how to get a globally optimal solution by deriving the maximum likelihood estimate analytically.
In the EM algorithm for solving this problem, we assume that we know from which Gaussian each point originated.
Once the EM algorithm has converged, we know for certain from which Gaussian each point originated.
The EM algorithm for this problem guarantees that the likelihood of the data never decreases from one iteration to the next.

questions.content: Assume you have points that are each generated by one of 2 possible Gaussians (GMM). Which of the following is true?

questions.title: EM/GMM [2 pts]
questions.content:
Which of the following is true about the EM algorithm as discussed in class for Gaussian Mixture Models?

  1. The choice of initial values of parameters of the Gaussian affects the final estimates.
  2. The algorithm is guaranteed to converge.
  3. The algorithm is guaranteed to converge to a global maxima.
  4. The estimate of the parameters obtained at the end is the Maximum Likelihood Estimate.

questions.title: EM/GMM [3 pts]
questions.content:
Your friend owns K identical looking coins with unknown probabilities \(p_1, p_2, …. , p_K\) of landing on heads. He hides these coins from you and with unknown probability \(\lambda_j\) decides to flip coin j. You observe this process N times and are allowed to observe the result of the flip each time. Your friend then places the coins in a line such that the coins are ordered by their probability to come up heads and challenges you to guess each coin’s probability to land on heads.

After thinking for a bit, you realize that if you could use your observations of the coin flips to estimate \(p_1, p_2, …. , p_K\), then you could order your estimates and assign them to the ordered coins. Since you are taking 10-601 and know how to work with the MLE (maximum likelihood estimator), you try to estimate the parameters by maximizing the likelihood of the data.

Let \(X= \{x_1, x_2, …. , x_N\}\) be the observed coin flips. where \(x_i = 1\) if the ith coin flip landed on heads, \(x_i = 0\) otherwise. Let \(Z = \{z_{11}, \cdots, z_{N1},z_{12}, \cdots, z_{N2}, \cdots, z_{1K}, \cdots, z_{NK}\}\) and each \(z_{ij} = 1\) if flip i was from coin \(j, z_{ij}\) = 0 otherwise.

Which of the options below is a correct way to model the complete likelihood of the data, P(X,Z)? You may assume that your friend chooses the coin to flip independently and that each coin flip is independent of one another, given the parameters of the coin.

questions.title: EM/GMM [3 pts]

choices.answer: The maximum likelihood estimates do not exist because there are latent variables in the likelihood function.
You want to find a global maximum for the likelihood, but finding the maximum likelihood estimates only guarantees us a local maximum.
There does not exist a deterministic algorithm to find estimates that maximize the global likelihood. At best you can find estimates that locally maximize likelihood.
Finding the maximum likelihood estimates will be computationally difficult for large N and K.

questions.content:
NOTE : This is continued from the previous question.

You plan to solve for the probability \(p_1, p_2, …. , p_K\) and all the \(z_{ij}\) by finding the maximizer of your likelihood function in closed form. However, your friend Amy thinks this approach is not a good idea; what valid argument do you think she will give?

questions.title: EM/GMM [3 pts]
questions.content:
NOTE : This is continued from the previous question.

You decide to use the EM algorithm learned in class to estimate the coin’s biases. Suppose, k = 2 and you observe the coin flips: H, T, H, H. 

You suspect that \(p_1\) might be around 0.4, and \(p_2\) might be around 0.8, so you initialize the initial coin biases to be \(p_1^{(0)}\) = 0.4 and \(p_2^{(0)}\) = 0.8. You also assume that the coins are equally likely to be picked, so \(\lambda_1^{(0)} = \lambda_2^{(0)} = 0.5\).

Given these as the starting parameters, the next step is to estimate \(z_{ij}\). For the sake of convenience, let \(\theta^{(0)}\) represent the initial parameters. What is \( E[z_{ij} | x_i, \theta^{(0)}] \) when \(x_i = 1\)(the ith coin flip landed on heads) and j = 2? Note that the EM algorithm then uses these estimates of \(z_{ij}\) to compute better estimates for your parameters.

questions.title: PCA [2 pts]
questions.content:
In the following plot, a train set of data points belonging to two classes on a two dimensional space are given, where the original features are the coordinates (x, y).

[True/False]  You can use the Principal Component representation of the data to create a classification rule that has 100% accuracy on the train set.

questions.content:
In the following plot, a train set of data points belonging to two classes on a two dimensional space are given, where the original features are the coordinates (x, y).

[True/False]  You can use the Principal Component representation of the data to create a classification rule that has 100% accuracy on the train set.

questions.title: PCA [2 pts]
questions.content:
In the following plot, a train set of data points belonging to two classes on a two dimensional space are given, where the original features are the coordinates (x, y).

[True/False]  You can use the Principal Component representation of the data to create a classification rule that has 100% accuracy on the train set.

questions.title: PCA [1 pt]
questions.content: [True/False] The goal of PCA is to interpret the underlying structure of the data in terms of the principal components that are best at predicting the labels of the training points.

questions.title: PCA [1 pt]
questions.content: [True/False] The output of PCA is a new representation of the data that is always of lower dimensionality than the original feature representation.

questions.title: PCA [1 pt]
questions.content: [True/False] The output of PCA is ordered according to the amount of variance each new feature contains.

questions.title: PCA [1 pt]
questions.content: [True/False] The output of PCA is at least as good as the original feature representation when the task we are trying to solve is unsupervised.

questions.title: PCA [2 pts]

choices.answer: a point with large feature values in \(Z_1\) and small feature values in \(Z_2\)
choices.feedback: The first scenario will be more common. Most of the variance of the training data is captured by the top principal components, therefore this features will tend to have higher values.

choices.answer: a point with the large feature values in \(Z_2\) and small feature values in \(Z_1\).
choices.feedback: The first scenario will be more common. Most of the variance of the training data is captured by the top principal components, therefore this features will tend to have higher values.

choices.answer: a point with the large feature values in \(Z_2\) and large feature values in \(Z_1\) as well.
choices.feedback: The first scenario will be more common. Most of the variance of the training data is captured by the top principal components, therefore this features will tend to have higher values.

choices.answer: a point with the small feature values in \(Z_2\) and small feature values in \(Z_1\) as well.
choices.feedback: The first scenario will be more common. Most of the variance of the training data is captured by the top principal components, therefore this features will tend to have higher values.

questions.content: Assume we apply PCA to a matrix \(X \in R^{n\times m}\) and obtain a set of PCA features, \(Z \in R^{n \times m}\). We divide this set into two, \(Z_1\) and \(Z_2\). The first set, \(Z_1\), corresponds to the top principal components. The second set, \(Z_2\), corresponds to the remaining principal components. Which is more common in the training data:

questions.title: PCA [2 pts]
questions.content:
Consider 3 data points in \(R^2\): (-1, -1), (0,0), (1,1). Determine what the first principal component is. Let \(P_1 \in R^2\) be that first principal component. And
let the first and second entry of \(P_1\) be \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\). What is the numerical value of \(\alpha*\beta?\)

questions.title: PCA [2 pts]
questions.content:
NOTE : This is continued from the previous question.

If we project the original data points into the 1-d subspace by the first principal component you computed in the previous question, let the variance of the projected data be \(\alpha\) and the mean of the projected data be \(\beta\). What is the value of \(\alpha + \beta\)? (For computing variance, use biased variance formula, not the unbiased variance formula)

questions.title: PCA [2 pts]
questions.content:
NOTE : This is continued from the previous question.

For the projected data you just obtained above, now if we represent them in the original 2-d space and consider them as the reconstruction of the original data points, what is the reconstruction error?

Reconstruction error : $$\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n ||p(x_i) - x_i||_2^2$$ where \(x_i\) is the i th point and  \(p(x_i)\) is the reconstructed point for \(x_i\)

questions.title: PCA [2 pts]
questions.content: For the data set shown below, what are the first and the second principal components? Options are given in the form of (first PC, second PC).

questions.title: PCA [3 pts]
questions.content:
NOTE : This is continued from the previous question.

What is the third principal component in the plot from the previous question?

questions.title: Clustering [3 pts]
questions.content:
Recall that in k−means clustering we attempt to find k cluster centers \(c_j \in R^d, j\in \{1,\dots,k\}\) such that the total distance between each datapoint and the nearest cluster center is minimized. Then the objective function is $$\sum_{i=1}^n min_{j\in\{1,\dots ,k\}} ||x_i - c_j||^2 \hspace{20mm}(1)$$ In other words, we attempt to find \(c_1 ,\dots ,c_k\) that minimizes (1), where n is the number of data points. To do so, we iterate between assigning \(x_i\) to the nearest cluster center and updating each cluster center \(c_j\) to the average of all points assigned to the j th cluster.  Instead of holding the number of clusters k fixed, your friend John tries to minimize (1) over k. Yet, you found out this idea to be a bad one. 

Specifically, you convinced John by providing two values \(\alpha\), the minimum possible value of (1), and \(\beta\), the value of k when (1) is minimized. 

What is the value of \(\alpha + \beta\) when \(n=100\)?

questions.title: Clustering [3 pts]
questions.content:
NOTE : This is continued from the previous question.

We want to see how k-means clustering works on a single dimension. Consider the case in which k = 3 and we have 4 data points \(x_1=1, x_2 = 2, x_3 = 5, x_4 =7\). What is the optimal value of the objective (1) ?

questions.title: Clustering [2 pts]

choices.answer: After the first iteration of the algorithm, the set of data IDs assigned to \(c_1\) is {1,2,3,4}
After the first iteration of the algorithm, the set of data IDs assigned to \(c_2\) is {3,4,5,6,7}
After the first iteration of the algorithm, the set of data IDs assigned to \(c_1\) is {1,2}
After the first iteration of the algorithm, the set of data IDs assigned to \(c_2\) is {4,5,6,7}

questions.content:
Consider the following data set consisting of the points on \(\mathbb{R}^2\):

In order to answer this question and the two subsequent questions, you have to run k-means algorithm. The parameters for the algorithm are as follows: \(k=2\), \(c_1= (1.0,1.0)\), \(c_2=(5.0,7.0)\) where \(c_1\) and \(c_2\) are initial centroids. Note that when there are multiple centroids with minimum distance to a point \(p\), the point \(p\) is assigned to the centroid with smaller ID. For instance, \(c_1\) has ID 1 and \(c_2\) has ID 2. 

Which of the following is true when you run k-means algorithm on the given dataset with specified parameters? 

Clarification : 

    1. One iteration includes updating the assignment of points to clusters and updating centroids for each cluster

questions.title: Clustering [2 pts]
questions.content:
NOTE : This is continued from question 21.

After you completed the first iteration of k-means algorithm (assignment of points and update of cluster centroids) on the dataset provided in question 21 with specified parameters, what is the value of the new \(c_1\)?

questions.title: Clustering [2 pts]
questions.content:
NOTE : This is continued from question 21.

When you run k-means algorithm on the dataset provided in question 21 with specified parameters, after how many iterations does the algorithm converge? 

Clarification : 

  1. One iteration includes updating the assignment of points to clusters and updating centroids for each cluster
  2. If the assignment of points to clusters and the value of cluster centroids at \(k+1\)th iteration are not changed from those of \(k\)th iteration, we define that k-means algorithm converged in \(k\) iterations.

questions.content:

You can use either decimal representation (e.g. 11111111111.111) or scentific representation (e.g. 11111.11e+001).

questions.title: K-means Experiments [3 pts]
questions.content:
Note: This question is based on material discussed in Problem 2 of the homework assignment. Please read through Problem 2 before answering this question.

After conducting \(k\)-means clustering on the reduced dataset, you get the center of each cluster in C for the reduced dataset, how do you find the center of each cluster for the original dataset?

This question should be answered by short sentences. You can either describe the process by plain text or paste the codes you wrote.

questions.title: Clustering [0 pt]
questions.content:
NOTE : This is continued from the question 21.

Now that you have implemented your own k-means algorithm in either Octave or Python, we can check if our answers to questions 21, 22, and 23, which you have derived by doing k-means algorithm on paper, match with the results when we run our k-means code on the same data set.

For this question, run your k-means code on the same data set provided in question 23, and compare the results with your answers to questions 21, 22, and 23. 

Do the results match? Please answer in Yes/No format.
